page.title: 15Droitwich - Farming
page.content: The land in the Droitwich area consists of heavy clay, except for a band of light soil running east/west one mile south of Droitwich. On average there is 25 ins of rainfall a year, which is just above the national average. Most of the farming in this area is mixed. A typical farm has much of the land turned over to grass. The animals are kept fed on this. Sometimes, the grass runs out so rape is grown. A small amount of land has wheat and barley growing on it. Cattle pigs and sheep are also kept on such a farm. Most of the lambs are slaughtered but about 4 are kept for breeding. The Freisan cows give milk, which is collected twice a day by tankers from the Milk Marketing Board. The pigs are sold as pork.
